dmca.title: RE: Spam Criminals Feedback
dmca.body:
Return-Path: <[Private]@internetadvancement.com> Received: from control-access16.com (control-access16.com [216.118.66.248] (may be forged)) by mercury.sabren.com (8.11.6/8.11.6) with SMTP id h62Kor621462 for ; Wed, 2 Jul 2003 16:50:56 -0400 Received: (qmail 123 invoked from network); 2 Jul 2003 20:43:01 -0000 Received: from softdnserror (HELO paddy) (207.101.233.11) by control-access16.com with SMTP; 2 Jul 2003 20:43:01 -0000 From: "[Private]@internetadvancement.com" To: "[Private]" <[Private]@shrednow.com> Subject: RE: Spam Criminals Feedback Date: Wed, 2 Jul 2003 13:44:45 -0700 Message-ID: MIME-Version: 1.0 Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii" Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit X-Priority: 3 (Normal) X-MSMail-Priority: Normal X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook IMO, Build 9.0.2416 (9.0.2910.0) X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1106 Importance: Normal In-Reply-To: Status: -----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE----- Hash: SHA1 Dear Arthur, The website URL that you listed has nothing to do with any legal definition of spam or UCE. Your site is ambiguous in its intent. Except for using the language that anyone listed on your website comes under a legal term of "Criminal." This sort of language is libelous to our company. Our email is sent out not only in a perfectly legal fashion, but a personal and professional format. To make things brief, your listing our company as a criminal entity on your website defames us and our organization. This email is a notification to the addressee to cease and desist the publication of our website address, company name, and any reference to Internet Advancement under a false heading. If you are unfamiliar with the legal definitions of spam or UCE and would like to take a refresher course, I've prepared these links outlining the laws that apply to Washington State Entities. - --Orion RCW 19.190.030 Unpermitted or misleading electronic mail -- Violation of consumer protection act. (1) It is a violation of the consumer protection act, chapter 19.86 RCW, to conspire with another person to initiate the transmission or to initiate the transmission of a commercial electronic mail message that: (a) Uses a third party's internet domain name without permission of the third party, or otherwise misrepresents or obscures any information in identifying the point of origin or the transmission path of a commercial electronic mail message; or (b) Contains false or misleading information in the subject line. (2) It is a violation of the consumer protection act, chapter 19.86 RCW, to assist in the transmission of a commercial electronic mail message, when the person providing the assistance knows, or consciously avoids knowing, that the initiator of the commercial electronic mail message is engaged, or intends to engage, in any act or practice that violates the consumer protection act. (3) The legislature finds that the practices covered by this chapter are matters vitally affecting the public interest for the purpose of applying the consumer protection act, chapter 19.86 RCW. A violation of this chapter is not reasonable in relation to the development and preservation of business and is an unfair or deceptive act in trade or commerce and an unfair method of competition for the purpose of applying the consumer protection act, chapter 19.86 RCW. [1999 c 289 ? 3; 1998 c 149 ? 4.] RCW 19.190.020 Unpermitted or misleading electronic mail -- Prohibition. (1) No person may initiate the transmission, conspire with another to initiate the transmission, or assist the transmission, of a commercial electronic mail message from a computer located in Washington or to an electronic mail address that the sender knows, or has reason to know, is held by a Washington resident that: (a) Uses a third party's internet domain name without permission of the third party, or otherwise misrepresents or obscures any information in identifying the point of origin or the transmission path of a commercial electronic mail message; or (b) Contains false or misleading information in the subject line. (2) For purposes of this section, a person knows that the intended recipient of a commercial electronic mail message is a Washington resident if that information is available, upon request, from the registrant of the internet domain name contained in the recipient's electronic mail address. [1999 c 289 ? 2; 1998 c 149 ? 3.] RCW 19.190.050 Blocking of commercial electronic mail by interactive computer service -- Immunity from liability. (1) An interactive computer service may, upon its own initiative, block the receipt or transmission through its service of any commercial electronic mail that it reasonably believes is, or will be, sent in violation of this chapter. (2) No interactive computer service may be held liable for any action voluntarily taken in good faith to block the receipt or transmission through its service of any commercial electronic mail which it reasonably believes is, or will be, sent in violation of this chapter. [1998 c 149 ? 6.] - -----Original Message----- From: [Private][mailto:[private]@shrednow.com] Sent: Wednesday, July 02, 2003 1:06 PM To: [Private]@internetadvancement.com Subject: Re: Spam Criminals Feedback Orion, I will be glad to remove you from the Spam Criminals list as long as you follow the instructions at http://www.shrednow.com/spamcrime/spammeroff.html . Your organization sent me unsolicited commercial email, which is my (and many others') definition of spam. There was no form on my website that led to the email address where your organization sent this email. As such, it qualifies as spam under the definitions used on my opinion site Spam Criminals. internetadvancement.com spam Return-Path: <[Private]@internetadvancement.com>
Received: from localhost.localdomain ([211.42.48.136])
by mercury.sabren.com (8.11.6/8.11.6) with ESMTP id gBMNPlI25788
for ; Sun, 22 Dec 2002 18:25:47 -0500
Received: from internetadvancement.com ([217.52.253.70])
by localhost.localdomain (8.11.6/8.11.6) with SMTP id gBMMUPS18897
for ; Mon, 23 Dec 2002 07:30:28 +0900
Date: Mon, 23 Dec 2002 07:30:28 +0900
Message-Id: <200212222230.gBMMUPS18897@localhost.localdomain>
From: [Private]@internetadvancement.com
To: OMITTED
Subject: About your website
X-Priority: 3
Status: RO

Hello,

I am sending this message to you from your website to invite you to be a part of 4GreatBuys.com. I have just been clicking around your website, and I believe your site would be a great addition to our existing stores.

I would love to speak with you further. I can be reached at [Private]8 between 7:30am - 4:30pm PST. Or if you would like to send me your phone number and the best time to contact you, I would be happy to give you a call.

I look forward to hearing back from you.

Have A Great Day!


Wishing You Success,
[Private]
[Private]@internetadvancement.com
>Thank you for your Spam Criminals feedback. This message was >emailed: [Private] >[Private]@internetadvancement.com >Hello, >I was scanning the search engine of google and found that your site >has listed our domain as "Spam Criminals." Please remove our domain >from your list as we do no spamming. There are some obvious reasons >for this if you are interested. You may contact me directly at >orion@internetadvancement.com with any questions. If I do not hear >anything back from you I will assume you have removed the domain >from your list and will check back later to verify. I appreciate >your prompt response. > >--Orion -----BEGIN PGP SIGNATURE----- Version: PGP 8.0.2 iQA/AwUBPwNEO2VvkoOsZcEmEQIPkwCfdjv2whuBf10418MT/whOoD3jBX4An0v5 nPNyNIjVBuHXIkvnUgsYSaeU =jCkB -----END PGP SIGNATURE-----
